content: I don't see what the purpose of hiding the docs of one method at a time are, and the toggle adds a lot of visual weight.
I'm strongly in favor :thumbs_up:

When teaching people Rust, I encourage them to collapse all the docs (e.g. for Option or Iterator). Then, skim the function names and signatures, showing the documentation for the ones they find interesting.
I do much the same when exploring a new crate, or seeing what functions have been added recently to the stdlib.

my proposal for that is:

  • hide the toggles when they're in open state and have never been closed.
  • show the toggles after "collapse all docs."

Conversely, I've found myself very annoyed at the "recent" change that makes it so that clicking anywhere in the doc text toggles it. I'm not a hardcore highlight-while-I-read web user, but I guess I click more than I expect.

clicking anywhere in the doc text

This was an accidental side effect of some refactoring to use <details> tags. Fixed on nightly (and maybe beta by now?)
Actually that fix seems to have made it all the way to stable. Please let me know if you're still seeing that behavior.
You might see on docs.rs with crates compiled with the faulty version too.

Jake Goulding said:

When teaching people Rust, I encourage them to collapse all the docs (e.g. for Option or Iterator). Then, skim the function names and signatures, showing the documentation for the ones they find interesting.

I'm not proposing to remove the feature you describe, of collapsing all docs. I'm proposing to remove the method-by-method toggles that collapse a particular method's docs.

jsha said:

my proposal for that is:

  • hide the toggles when they're in open state and have never been closed.
  • show the toggles after "collapse all docs."

Hmm, conditional behavior like that seems complicated and unnecessary. I don't think @Jake Goulding's use case would be impacted by removing the method-by-method toggles altogether (as proposed here).
I don’t see how “expand the docs for the method that looks interesting” can be done without a button to expand the docs for a method. Perhaps I am not understanding your suggestion.
My eyes skipped over that, sorry :sweat_smile:
I think @jsha's idea is reasonable then.
I've practically never used the collapse/expand buttons (global or local) myself, so I think it's easy for me to miss particular use cases like that.
I don’t claim that my usage is the majority, just that it’s non-zero.
Yeah, well my usage might be the one in the minority for all I know ;)

I actually put up a PR demonstrating my proposed approach, about six months ago: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/86154

Including a demo: https://jacob.hoffman-andrews.com/rust/invisible-toggles/std/string/struct.String.html#implementations
also, I do think there are a lot of people, particularly rustc maintainers, who regularly use the "collapse all and then toggle interesting things" flow.

Rather than collapse and expand elements, I just scan the names in the left hand column and click through to the interesting method. I think adding the signature as a tool tip would make this method at least as useful as collapsing all. I'd love to see all the collapsers removed they contribute to the overall noisey feel of rustdoc that makes it intimidating to newcomers

the signature as a tool tip

Which means that you would have to move the mouse, wait 1-2 seconds for the tip to appear, read it, move the mouse, read it, etc.. You certainly would not be able to scan quickly if it's relegated as a tooltip.
As a tooltip doesn't sound like a good idea to me either.

Usually I scan based on name primarily and want the signature as a kind of second stage of triage, so a tooltip would be useful for me because I would scan over a few 10s of methods, hover over one, then click it if the sig looks right
(Also tooltips are basically free in terms of clutter since they don't appear unless you hover)
Yeah just names you can click and also a tooltip if you dont want to click sounds ideal actually
The left column already doesn't have signatures so it's actually just an improvement over the current situation
